thread.title: Why should Seattle accept growth? Maybe city should limit it
thread.title_full: Why should Seattle accept growth? Maybe city should limit it | The Seattle Times

author: Letters editor
title: Why should Seattle accept growth? Maybe city should limit it
text:
Mayor Ed Murray reminds us that among the painful effects of Seattle’s growth are: “whether [families] will be able to afford rising rents, whether they will be able to get where they need to go, and if their kids will have access to quality education.” [" Seattle meets growth’s challenges ” Opinion, Aug. 19].
To those disturbing consequences of growth he could have added: disruption of traditional neighborhoods, gridlock on our streets, overburdened parks and other facilities, greater pollution.
Yet nowhere in his commentary does the mayor say anything about trying to limit the growth that will exacerbate all those problems.
We know that those engaged in property development, landlords, businesses and the like happily prosper from unrestrained growth. But what do the rest of us get out of it, other than more grief?
Most Read Stories Wind-whipped wildfire kills 3 firefighters, injures 4 near Twisp No bodies found in wreckage of Bremerton motel Cascadia fault chatters and pops with little quakes When fire chief called for help, and no one was left State cracks down on fraudulent immigration aid It would be good for the mayor to tell us why we should accept the distressing consequences of growth without making an effort to limit it.
Lester Goldstein, Seattle
Letters editor : letters@seattletimes.com .
